H0.text: An electron is a particle type that can be identified as being from a specific element.

H1.text: Atom is the particle type that can be identified as being from a specific element.

H2.text: Neutron is a particle type that can be identified as being from a specific element.

H3.text: Proton is the particle type that can be identified as being from a specific element.

A4.text: The number of protons in an atom was found to be equal to the element's ordinal number on the periodic table and therefore provided a simple and clear-cut way of distinguishing the elements from each other.

A5.text: The chemical elements are distinguished from each other by the number of protons that are in their atoms.

A6.text: The standard model of an atom is of a dense nucleus of charged protons and electrically-neutral neutrons, surrounded by an electrically-bound cloud of low mass, negatively charged electrons.

A7.text: Atoms of the same element can have different numbers of neutrons in their nuclei, known as isotopes of the element.

A8.text: The atomic number or nuclear charge number (symbol Z) of a chemical element is the charge number of its atomic nucleus.
